titleStmt.title: Defensio of the Sale of an Outbuilding

msContents.summary: A defensio of person X's right to sell an outbuilding. Person X has acquired some real estate from Y, including house(s) and half of an outbuilding without anyone disputing this transaction. After that, X has further sold a part of the property, namely (at least) two ﬁrst-ﬂoor rooms with half of the outbuilding, to Z. Now a fourth person, W, has testiﬁed that the possession of this half of the outbuilding belongs to some other people. The document was written by X (the seller) for Z (the buyer). In it he conﬁrms the transactions and states that the new person W must bring evidence for his testimony, and announces that he will sue a person called Georgios, son and of Stephanos, son of Leontios. This document might thus be dealing with the same block of houses which was under dispute in 39. In 39 there are several references to defensio, which seems to mean the seller’s obligation to defend his original ownership and thus his right to sell the property to the buyer in case someone else claims the ownership afterwards.

msItemStruct.note: Written in one wide column along the ﬁbers. The right margin (3.5 cm) is preserved, while the left margin may be visible in only one fragment. Extant middle part concists of ten lines (plus traces from two others) and it is difﬁcult to estimate how many lines are missing from the top and the lower part. Perhaps the fragments of XXIX L contain missing pieces. If the size of the roll is correctly estimated, the roll originally consisted of four papyrus sheets. The greatest part of fourth, which only contained the right margin, was cut off. Τhe hand is an upright cursive, ﬂuent and practiced.

div.ab: (Lines 2–3) [I agree] . . . to have . . . [and] registered the ownership . . . of all the (real estate) which the above-mentioned [person Y] has sold to me . . . [by] him to [me] through a written deed of sale, and no person in whatever way or time has questioned it . . . (Lines 4–6) . . . at all on account of [these] dwellings or of a part of them or of the above-written one half of the said outbuilding, and when I have sold to you . . . the two ﬁrst-ﬂoor rooms including one half of the said outbuilding, through a deed of sale made by me to you, no one, neither me nor anyone after this . . . nor disagreed at all as far as regards the same sale, as I have given to you concretely the possession and you received it free from disturbance. (Line 7) . . . this being so, [person W] at present ﬁled a suit saying that some people have the ownership of one half of the said outbuilding which I have sold to you . . . (Lines 8–9) . . . do this . . . the neighbors will no longer satisfy us, trying to bring an action for it in order that the [possession] should be invalid. For the most honorable [woman W?] should . . . [show through] proceedings against both of us present the legal action and lawsuit over this . . . they try . . . so that even I . . . with the pretext . . . (Lines 10–11) . . . from [now] I will sue Georgios, the son (and) heir of the above-mentioned most blessed Stephanos, son of Leontios, who at that time possessed . . . he . . . him to [give] security for the whole property . . .
